qa_pairs.question: What is the primary source of funding for RightChange.com, and how does this relate to its political activities as described in the context?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>RightChange.com's primary source of funding came from Fred Eshelman, a North Carolina pharmaceutical business owner, who contributed millions of dollars to the organization.<cite>[S6][S10][S15][S16]</cite></statement> <statement>Eshelman's financial support enabled RightChange.com to engage in political activities such as funding campaign ads, promoting conservative candidates, and criticizing Democratic policies, aligning with his Republican affiliations and interests.<cite>[S2][S4][S8][S9][S11]</cite></statement> <statement>Additionally, RightChange.com's funding structure, including contributions from Eshelman and other health industry figures, reinforced its focus on conservative political messaging and accountability campaigns.<cite>[S15][S17][S18]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] RightChange.com


# RightChange.com



**RightChange.com** was an American conservative political group. [S2] It was devoted to electing conservative U.S. [S3] Republican Party candidates, thus the reference to the political right in its name. [S4] It spent millions supporting Republican candidates in the 2010 general election. [S5] It defined itself as an organization that "engages Americans through informed, fact-based content delivered in a creative format and through multimedia platforms to allow viewers to develop their own conclusions about the most critical economic and national security policies of our day. [S6] RightChange cuts through the political spin by using politicians’ own words, votes and actions to hold them accountable." Its funding mostly came from Fred Eshelman, a North Carolina pharmaceutical business owner. [S7] ## Campaigns and actions

In a last-minute campaign ad, RightChange used images from the September 2001 World Trade Center attacks to assert that Democratic presidential candidate Barack Obama would "undermine the terror strategy that protects us". [S8] During the 2008 U.S. [S9] presidential election, RightChange sponsored television commercials and said that "For years, John McCain warned of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac’s risk to the economy and pushed for reform" while "Democrats defended Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac." RightChange also attacked Democratic candidate Barack Obama, claiming that his "economic proposals stick small businesses with the Bill for the Wall Street Bailout."

The Associated Press reported on September 16, 2008, that RightChange.com "plans to spend about $1.5 million in the next two weeks on national cable networks including Fox News Channel, CNN, and CNN Headline News, said spokesman Tim Pittman. [S10] Rightchange.com is financed largely by pharmaceutical executive Fred Eshelman, who has given more than $200,000 to Republican candidates and party organizations since 2002, according to Federal Election Commission records. [S11] The Tax Foundation, a tax research group based in Washington, D.C. [S12] that has been operating since 1937, analyzed the claims made by RightChange in one of its ads and concluded that they were "spreading nonsense ... [S13] so ridiculous that I'm almost at a loss for words ... [S14] an outright lie."


## Funding

According to National Public Radio, RightChange "reported $2.7 million in contributions from its president, Fred Eshelman, CEO of PPD, a pharmaceutical research firm in North Carolina. [S15] Eshelman donated $3.38 million to RightChange in 2010. [S16] PPD's chairman, Ernest Mario, gave an additional $1 million. [S17] Mario also runs Capnia Inc., a Palo Alto, Calif.-based company developing a system to treat migraines using medical gas." NPR noted that "RightChange.com's other directors also have connections to the health industry. [S18] Board member Jeff Barnhart is CEO of Cabarrus Community Health Centers, which RightChange's corporate secretary, Fletcher Hartsell, helped found. [S19] Both Barnhart and Hartsell are Republican state legislators in North Carolina."

[S1] RightChange.com


# RightChange.com



**RightChange.com** was an American conservative political group. qa_pairs.question: How did RightChange.com's approach to political messaging involve using specific strategies, and what was the Tax Foundation's response to these strategies?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>RightChange.com's approach to political messaging involved using specific strategies such as leveraging politicians’ own words, votes, and actions to hold them accountable, as well as employing multimedia platforms to deliver fact-based content. Additionally, it utilized emotionally charged imagery, such as references to the September 2001 World Trade Center attacks, to criticize Democratic candidates like Barack Obama. These strategies aimed to frame conservative narratives and challenge opponents through targeted advertising.<cite>[S5][S6][S7][S8]</cite></statement><statement>The Tax Foundation responded to RightChange.com's claims by analyzing one of its ads and condemning them as "spreading nonsense," "so ridiculous that I'm almost at a loss for words," and "an outright lie," directly rejecting the validity of RightChange's messaging.<cite>[S12][S13][S14]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: How did RightChange.com's 2008 campaign strategies target specific political figures, and what were the claims made against them?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>RightChange.com's 2008 campaign strategies targeted specific political figures by using television commercials and ads to highlight policy differences and attack opponents. For example, they asserted that Democratic presidential candidate Barack Obama would "undermine the terror strategy that protects us" by associating him with the September 2001 World Trade Center attacks. They also claimed that John McCain warned about Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac’s risks while Democrats defended them, and accused Obama of proposing economic policies that would burden small businesses with the Wall Street Bailout. These strategies aimed to frame Republicans as fiscally responsible and Democrats as supportive of risky economic practices.<cite>[S8][S9]</cite></statement>

[S1] RightChange.com


# RightChange.com



**RightChange.com** was an American conservative political group. [S2] It was devoted to electing conservative U.S. [S3] Republican Party candidates, thus the reference to the political right in its name. [S4] It spent millions supporting Republican candidates in the 2010 general election. [S5] It defined itself as an organization that "engages Americans through informed, fact-based content delivered in a creative format and through multimedia platforms to allow viewers to develop their own conclusions about the most critical economic and national security policies of our day. [S6] RightChange cuts through the political spin by using politicians’ own words, votes and actions to hold them accountable." Its funding mostly came from Fred Eshelman, a North Carolina pharmaceutical business owner. [S7] ## Campaigns and actions

In a last-minute campaign ad, RightChange used images from the September 2001 World Trade Center attacks to assert that Democratic presidential candidate Barack Obama would "undermine the terror strategy that protects us". [S8] During the 2008 U.S. [S9] presidential election, RightChange sponsored television commercials and said that "For years, John McCain warned of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac’s risk to the economy and pushed for reform" while "Democrats defended Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac." RightChange also attacked Democratic candidate Barack Obama, claiming that his "economic proposals stick small businesses with the Bill for the Wall Street Bailout."

The Associated Press reported on September 16, 2008, that RightChange.com "plans to spend about $1.5 million in the next two weeks on national cable networks including Fox News Channel, CNN, and CNN Headline News, said spokesman Tim Pittman. [S10] Rightchange.com is financed largely by pharmaceutical executive Fred Eshelman, who has given more than $200,000 to Republican candidates and party organizations since 2002, according to Federal Election Commission records. [S11] The Tax Foundation, a tax research group based in Washington, D.C. [S12] that has been operating since 1937, analyzed the claims made by RightChange in one of its ads and concluded that they were "spreading nonsense ... [S13] so ridiculous that I'm almost at a loss for words ... [S14] an outright lie."


## Funding

According to National Public Radio, RightChange "reported $2.7 million in contributions from its president, Fred Eshelman, CEO of PPD, a pharmaceutical research firm in North Carolina. [S15] Eshelman donated $3.38 million to RightChange in 2010. [S16] PPD's chairman, Ernest Mario, gave an additional $1 million. [S17] Mario also runs Capnia Inc., a Palo Alto, Calif.-based company developing a system to treat migraines using medical gas." NPR noted that "RightChange.com's other directors also have connections to the health industry. [S18] Board member Jeff Barnhart is CEO of Cabarrus Community Health Centers, which RightChange's corporate secretary, Fletcher Hartsell, helped found. [S19] Both Barnhart and Hartsell are Republican state legislators in North Carolina."
